diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 38-year-old female who presents with a persistent upper abdominal discomfort that has been increasing in severity over the past three months. The discomfort is usually located in the upper abdomen and can be accompanied by bloating and a touch of queasiness. The patient reports that the discomfort is usually worse after meals and can last for a couple of hours. The patient also reports a family history of celiac disease and colon cancer.
Examination Items and Results:
The patient's examination items include a review of systems, a physical examination, and a review of her medical history. The patient reports a history of asthma and a current regimen of salbutamol inhalers and corticosteroids. The patient also reports a family history of celiac disease and colon cancer. The patient's blood pressure is within normal limits.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, it is possible that the patient has irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). However, further testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis. The patient's CT angiography revealed multiple small liver metastases, which may be related to a malignancy.
Treatment Plan:
The patient will be referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and treatment. The patient's current regimen of salbutamol inhalers and corticosteroids will continue. The patient will also be referred to a nutritionist for guidance on dietary changes that may help alleviate her symptoms. The patient will be followed closely by the gastroenterologist to monitor the progression of the liver metastases and to determine the best course of treatment.
Conclusion:
The patient presents with a persistent upper abdominal discomfort that may be related to irritable bowel syndrome or a malignancy. Further testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis. The patient's current regimen of salbutamol inhalers and corticosteroids will continue, and the patient will be referred to a nutritionist and a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and treatment.

Text.Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting one day.
Text.Present Illness: The patient experienced sudden severe pain in the upper abdomen one day ago without any apparent cause. The pain was constant, without episodic worsening or radiation to other areas. Symptoms included nausea and vomiting six times, with the vomitus consisting of gastric contents totaling about 1000 milliliters, containing no blood or worms.
Text.Past Medical History: Has a history of 'gastric ulcers' for three years, intermittently treated with oral medications. Denies history of 'hypertension, diabetes,' etc. No known drug or food allergies, no history of trauma or major surgery, and unclear history of vaccinations.
Text.Examinations:
Complete blood count shows: white blood cells at 2.46*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 79.0%, lymphocyte percentage at 14.0%, neutrophils count at 1.95*10^9/L, lymphocytes count at 0.34*10^9/L, hemoglobin at 159.00 g/L. 

 Biochemical report indicates: total protein at 45.7 g/L, albumin at 22.9 g/L, globulin at 23.60 g/L. 

 Upper abdominal CT: <\image00002.jpg>.
Text.Diagnosis: 1. Upper gastrointestinal perforation, 2. Cholecystolithiasis, cholecystitis, liver cyst, 3. Thickened ascending colon, 4. Acute diffuse peritonitis
Text.Treatment: Surgical repair of gastric pyloric perforation

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 65-year-old male who presents with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that has been persisting for 24 hours. The pain is located in the upper abdomen, specifically in the right upper quadrant, and is described as a constant, steady ache that does not respond to movement or change in position. The patient also reports nausea and vomiting, which has been affecting his daily activities and sleep. He has a history of belly ulcers and is currently taking medication for this condition. He has no history of high blood pressure or diabetes, and his past medical history is unremarkable. He has no recent travel history and is up to date on all his vaccinations.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient is found to be pale and diaphoretic. He is in moderate distress and has a guarding sensation in the right upper quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no rebound tenderness or guarding. There is no evidence of peritonitis or bowel obstruction. The patient's electrolytes, blood sugar, and liver function tests are normal.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings, a diagnosis of right upper quadrant abdominal pain secondary to a peptic ulcer is made. The patient's history of belly ulcers and current symptoms of nausea and vomiting are consistent with this diagnosis. The absence of peritonitis or bowel obstruction and normal laboratory results support this diagnosis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient is started on a course of antibiotics for the treatment of a possible bacterial infection. He is also prescribed proton pump inhibitors to reduce stomach acid production and alleviate his symptoms. The patient is advised to avoid spicy foods and alcohol, which can irritate the stomach lining and worsen his symptoms. He is also advised to maintain a regular diet and exercise routine to improve his overall health and reduce the risk of further complications. The patient is scheduled for follow-up with the gastroenterologist to monitor his progress and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 77-year-old male with a history of asthma and celiac disease, who presents with epigastric discomfort, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and a lack of flatulence for a week. He also has a family history of colon cancer and celiac disease. On examination, the patient is alert and oriented, with no signs of distress. His blood pressure is within normal limits, and his pulse is regular. There are no signs of dehydration or malnutrition. The patient's chest is clear, and there are no signs of wheezing or shortness of breath. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no masses or tenderness. The rectal examination is normal.
Diagnostic Evaluations:
The patient underwent a colonoscopy and an upper endoscopy, which were normal. He also had a blood test, which showed no significant abnormalities.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, it is possible that he has a gastrointestinal infection or a gastrointestinal disorder such as Crohn's disease or celiac disease. It is also possible that his symptoms could be related to a more serious condition such as a gastrointestinal cancer. The CT scan and MRI scans showed no significant abnormalities in the gastrointestinal tract.
Treatment Plan:
The patient will be prescribed antibiotics to treat any potential gastrointestinal infection. He will also be referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of his symptoms. If the symptoms persist, a biopsy of the gastrointestinal tract may be necessary to rule out a gastrointestinal cancer. The patient will also be advised to maintain a gluten-free diet to manage his celiac disease.
Conclusion:
The patient's symptoms are consistent with a gastrointestinal infection or a gastrointestinal disorder, and further diagnostic evaluations are recommended to rule out a gastrointestinal cancer. The patient will be prescribed antibiotics and referred to a gastroenterologist for further management of his symptoms.

Text.Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain and diarrhea for 3 days
Text.Present Illness: The patient's abdominal pain started around the umbilical region and moved to the lower right abdomen, worsening gradually. The pain is sharp and exacerbated by movement and eating. Oral painkillers like acetaminophen provide partial relief. The pain is associated with low-grade fever and decreased appetite. The patient reports watery stools five times per day, with no mucus or blood. Diarrhea started after taking antibiotics for a recent upper respiratory infection.
Text.Past Medical History: History of diabetes, well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. No history of surgeries. Smoker for 15 years. No family history of hereditary gastrointestinal diseases.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Abdomen soft with diffuse tenderness, most notable in the right iliac fossa with rebound tenderness.  

  Rovsing's sign: positive. Complete blood count shows elevated white blood cells and inflammatory markers (including ESR and CRP).  

  Liver and kidney functions normal. 

  Abdominal CT: <\image00006.jpg>
Text.Treatment: Limited cecum resection with appendectomy

Image.00006.jpg: Thickened colon wall with edematous folds suggesting pseudomembranous colitis. A 6cm lesion in the cecum, well-defined, with uniform fat density and no solid components.

Text.Chief Complaint: Two months post-acute pancreatitis recovery, experiencing abdominal bloating and decreased appetite for half a month.
Text.Present Illness: The patient developed persistent dull pain in the upper abdomen, particularly in the upper left quadrant, two months ago following overeating. Accompanied by nausea, vomiting of gastric contents, and developed generalized skin jaundice and dark urine. No chills, high fever, cough, phlegm, or breathing difficulties. Diagnosed at our hospital with acute pancreatitis and steatohepatitis.
Text.Past Medical History: History of acute pancreatitis two months ago treated with medication. Denies history of surgeries, trauma, drug allergies, and denies contact with infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.
Text.Examinations:
Laboratory findings show: ALT: 65.2 U/L, AST: 32.0 U/L, GGT: 126.0 U/L, TBIL: 22.5 umol/L, DBIL: 10.3 umol/L, IBIL: 12.2 umol/L, serum amylase 217 U/L.  

 CT shows: <\image00007.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Administered famotidine 20 mg in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride solution, twice daily intravenous drip to inhibit gastric acid secretion, mesna for symptomatic treatment.

Image.00007.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, no abnormal density in the parenchyma, no dilation in intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, normal size of the gallbladder, no clear positive stones. Pancreas is full, streak shadows around the pancreas, a round-like low-density shadow in front of the pancreas head, approximately 3.3*2.6 cm. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal area.

 CT shows: <\image00007.jpg>.

history.doctor:
Thank you for sharing the results of your CT scan with me. Based on the findings, it is likely that you have a mass in the tail of your pancreas, which is compressing the duodenum and causing malabsorption. This condition is known as a pancreatic pseudocyst. It is important to note that a pancreatic pseudocyst is a benign (non-cancerous) condition, but it can cause symptoms similar to those of a more serious condition such as a pancreas or abdominal organ cancer.
The next step would be to schedule a consultation with a surgeon to discuss the options for treatment. Treatment options may include observation, drainage of the pseudocyst, or surgical removal of the mass. The best course of action will depend on the size and location of the pseudocyst, as well as your overall health and medical history.
It is important to keep in mind that a pancreatic pseudocyst is a relatively common condition, and many people with pseudocysts do not require any treatment. However, if you are experiencing symptoms or if the pseudocyst is causing discomfort or other problems, it is important to seek medical attention and discuss treatment options with your healthcare provider.

The best course of action will depend on the size and location of the pseudocyst, as well as the patient's overall health and medical history.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 45-year-old male who presents with a chief complaint of right thumb pain that has been gradually worsening over the past year. The pain is described as a constant ache that turns into sharp jabs of pain when the thumb is moved or bumped. The patient also reports difficulty with gripping and handling small objects, and has noticed that the pain is particularly bad when trying to perform tasks that require fine motor skills, such as buttoning up his overalls or wrangling tiny seeds.
Past Medical History:
The patient reports a history of a crooked little finger on his right hand that has been present for the past ten years. He also reports no significant past medical history, other than the gradual worsening of the thumb pain over the past year.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient's right thumb appears to be slightly deformed, with a noticeable bend in the middle. There is no evidence of inflammation or swelling. The patient's range of motion is limited, with sharp pain being elicited when the thumb is moved or bumped. There is no evidence of infection or other obvious cause of the pain.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's history and examination, the most likely diagnosis is a repetitive strain injury, specifically a repetitive stress injury (RSI) of the right thumb. This is likely due to the patient's history of using his right hand for repetitive tasks, such as wrangling tiny seeds or buttoning up his overalls, which has caused strain on the thumb and led to the development of the RSI.
Treatment Plan:
The patient's treatment plan will focus on conservative management of the condition. This will include the use of ice and heat therapy to reduce inflammation and pain, as well as the use of over-the-counter pain medication to manage symptoms. The patient will also be advised to avoid activities that exacerbate the pain, such as gripping or handling small objects with the affected thumb. Physical therapy may also be recommended to help improve the patient's range of motion and strength in the affected thumb. If the condition does not improve with conservative management, surgical intervention may be considered.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 60-year-old female who presents with a chief complaint of black and thick stools that have been present for a week. She also reports feeling worn out and has noticed a change in her bowel movements, going to the bathroom once or twice a day, which is not her usual routine. She has no other symptoms such as abdominal pain, discomfort, diarrhea, or constipation. She has no travel history or recent changes in her diet or lifestyle that may have contributed to this symptom. She also reports no family history of digestive issues.
Examination:
During the physical examination, the patient appears to be generally well appearing and in no distress. She is not experiencing any abdominal pain or discomfort. Her bowel movements are regular, with no signs of diarrhea or constipation. There are no signs of dehydration or malnutrition. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits.
Diagnostic Assessment:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings, a diagnosis of constipation is likely. The patient's black and thick stools, along with her feeling worn out, are consistent with constipation. The change in her bowel movements, going to the bathroom once or twice a day, is also consistent with constipation. The absence of other symptoms such as abdominal pain, discomfort, diarrhea, or constipation, along with the normal vital signs, supports the diagnosis of constipation.
Treatment Plan:
The patient's treatment plan will focus on managing her constipation. This may include increasing her fiber intake, drinking more fluids, and incorporating physical activity into her daily routine. If these measures are not effective, medication may be prescribed to help stimulate bowel movements. It is important to monitor the patient's symptoms and response to treatment to ensure that the constipation is resolved and to prevent complications.

diagnosis_self:
Patient: A 66-year-old female corporate office worker presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of abdominal discomfort for the past 24 hours. She reports a persistent distension in her abdomen, which has been escalating in intensity over the course of the day. She also reports a shooting pain that extends to her back. She denies any recent travel history and reports a normal medical history. She reports a recent consumption of alcohol at dawn the previous day.
Examination: The patient is found to have a central abdominal discomfort, similar to bloating, which is severe and persistent. There is no tenderness or guarding. The patient reports that the pain extends to her back and is not alleviated by posture adjustments. There are no other symptoms noted.
Diagnosis: Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, it is possible that she has a condition called biliary colic. This is a condition that causes pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, which can be caused by a blockage of the bile duct. It is also possible that she has a gallstone that is causing the pain.
Treatment Plan: The patient is recommended to have an imaging test, such as an ultrasound or a CT scan, to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of treatment. The patient is also advised to avoid alcohol consumption and to follow a diet that is low in fat and high in fiber to help prevent future episodes of biliary colic. If the diagnosis is confirmed, treatment options may include medication to relieve the pain or surgery to remove the gallstone.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 70-year-old female who presents with a persistent upper left abdominal discomfort that has been present for 18 hours. The discomfort is described as a non-stop, intense, targeted agony that started around 2 AM and has persisted since then. The patient also reports a sudden onset of the pain, with no apparent trigger. She has no recent changes in her diet or stress levels. She has no recent medical examinations, such as X-rays or blood pressure monitoring. She also reports no nausea, vomiting, fever, or changes in bowel habits.
Examination Findings:
There are no significant changes in the patient's vital signs, such as blood pressure or heart rate. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no guarding or rebound tenderness. There are no signs of peritonitis or bowel obstruction. The patient's bowel movements are regular, without any signs of diarrhea or constipation.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is a gastrointestinal disorder, such as a peptic ulcer or a gastrointestinal infection. The sudden onset of the pain and the persistence of the discomfort suggest a possible acute process. The absence of fever and changes in bowel habits also rule out other potential causes, such as appendicitis or diverticulitis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient will be started on a course of antibiotics to treat any potential gastrointestinal infection. She will also be advised to avoid spicy foods and alcohol, which can irritate the stomach lining. If the symptoms persist, further diagnostic tests, such as an upper endoscopy or a CT scan, may be recommended to rule out other potential causes. The patient will also be advised to follow up with her primary care physician for further management.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 64-year-old male who presents with a chief complaint of intermittent upper left abdominal discomfort, particularly after consumption of lipid-rich meals. The discomfort is described as acidic bloating and has been present for approximately half a year. The patient also reports a past medical history of gallstones and hypertension, which is being managed with amlodipine. The patient's travel history is unremarkable and his past medical history is otherwise normal.
Examination Items and Results:
During the physical examination, the patient's blood pressure was found to be 160/90 mmHg, which is within the range of hypertension. No other abnormalities were detected during the examination.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, a diagnosis of gallstone-related pancreatitis is suspected. This is a complication of gallstones that can cause inflammation of the pancreas and lead to abdominal pain. The patient's symptoms of upper left abdominal discomfort, particularly after consumption of lipid-rich meals, are consistent with this diagnosis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient will be referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the gallstone-related pancreatitis. Treatment options may include medication to reduce the production of bile or surgery to remove the gallstones. The patient will also be advised to modify his diet to avoid high-fat foods that may exacerbate his symptoms.

Text.Chief Complaint: Persistent upper abdominal pain for one day
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports continuous severe pain in the upper abdomen that started one day ago without any apparent cause, radiating to the back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting three times, totaling approximately 800 milliliters of gastric content, without blood or worms. The pain did not alleviate after vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: History of Type 2 diabetes for 2 years, well-controlled with long-term oral medication.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Reduced abdominal breathing, slightly distended abdomen, no visible intestinal peristalsis or bowel waves, liver and spleen not palpable beyond the costal margin, generalized abdominal tenderness without rebound pain or muscle guarding, most severe in the upper left quadrant, no costovertebral angle tenderness.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00016.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells at 10.19*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 83.30%, lymphocyte percentage at 10.40%, neutrophil count at 8.49*10^9/L. Urinalysis: ketones +3, glucose +4, protein +3. Bicarbonate 12.81 mmol/L, blood sugar 14.44 mmol/L.
Text.Treatment: Exploratory laparotomy, splenectomy

Image.00016.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, decreased liver parenchymal density, no dilation in intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts, normal-sized gallbladder with no obvious stones. Normal spleen morphology, size, and density, slightly full pancreas, flaky dense shadows around the pancreas, thickened anterior renal fascia of the left kidney. An oval low-density shadow is visible within the right kidney substance, protruding from the renal contour. Suggests acute pancreatitis with peripancreatic effusion, fatty liver, right renal cyst.

Examination:
Upon examination, the patient appears to be in mild distress. She is experiencing fits, shaking spells, and bleeding from her right eyebrow area. There is no evidence of any other significant physical findings.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's history and examination, it is likely that the patient is experiencing a seizure disorder. The fits, shaking spells, and bleeding from the right eyebrow area are consistent with this diagnosis. The liver disease and past history of seizures also support this diagnosis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient should continue taking her medication as prescribed to manage the seizure disorder. It is also recommended that she schedule a follow-up appointment with her primary care physician to discuss her symptoms and determine the best course of treatment. The bleeding from the right eyebrow area should be evaluated by a medical professional to ensure that it is not a sign of a more serious condition.

Text.Chief Complaint: Chronic constipation for 20 years, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distension, and cessation of gas and bowel movements for 3 days.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports chronic constipation starting 20 years ago without an apparent cause, with hard stools occurring every 3 to 5 days and difficulty defecating, but without pain unless attempting to defecate, and no bloody or purulent stools. Previously diagnosed locally as 'constipation' and improved with oral laxatives (name and dosage unknown); intermittently medicated over 20 years. Constipation recurred 3 days ago, accompanied by episodic severe pain in the right upper abdomen, no radiation, and accompanied by nausea and vomiting five times of gastric contents, totaling about 1000 milliliters, without blood or worms. Abdominal pain slightly reduced after vomiting, accompanied by abdominal distension and cessation of gas and stool passage.
Text.Past Medical History: 20-year history of constipation.
Text.Examinations:
Upright abdominal plain film: <\image00018.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells 9.34*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage 88.60%, lymphocyte percentage 7.50%, neutrophils 8.27*10^9/L, lymphocytes 0.70*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Upon hospital admission, comprehensive tests were performed including continuous gastrointestinal decompression, warm soapy water enema of 800 ml, maintaining fluid and electrolyte and acid-base balance. The patient's underlying condition includes deficiency of yin and body fluids, dry and hard stools, lack of facial radiance, pale lips, and a fine and rough pulse. In traditional Chinese medicine, diagnosed as blood and yin deficiency, treatment should nourish yin and moisten dryness. Administered intestinal moistening pills and modified Shengjiang Chengqi Tang via gastric tube, 150 ml, tube clamped for 2 hours, resulting in substantial bowel movement the next day, symptoms and signs resolved.

Image.00018.jpg: No free gas under the diaphragm, intestinal gas and dilation in the right upper abdomen with a large gas-fluid level visible, no clear positive stone shadows in the path of both kidneys and ureters, both abdominal fat lines are still clear. Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the upper right abdomen one day after cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports that one month ago, she underwent a 'cholecystectomy and choledocholithotomy' due to 'gallbladder stones and common bile duct stones' at another hospital, with good postoperative recovery. One day ago, she experienced sudden severe continuous pain in the upper right abdomen without a clear cause, which was unbearable and radiated to the right shoulder and back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without bile or coffee-ground material. The pain did not lessen after vomiting and was accompanied by fever with a body temperature of 37.8°C, no chills, and no jaundice.
Text.Past Medical History: History of gallbladder and common bile duct stones for 6 years, long-term intermittent medication use, underwent cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Flat abdomen, localized tenderness in the upper right abdomen and mid upper abdomen, no rebound tenderness or muscle tension, tympanic abdomen on percussion, bowel sounds 4-6 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard.

 Complete blood count: WBC: 5.98*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage: 71.00%, lymphocyte percentage: 22.30%; neutrophil count: 3.97*10^9/L, lymphocyte count: 1.24*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Treatment with cefoperazone sodium and sulbactam sodium, and omeprazole injections to inhibit gastric acid secretion; intravenous phenobarbital for spasmolytic and analgesic treatment.

Image.00019.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, with punctate low-density areas in the parenchyma, no dilation of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal areas, no fluid in the abdominal cavity.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 55-year-old male who presents with a chief complaint of a sudden onset of severe right-sided abdominal pain that started after a gall bladder surgery. The pain is described as shooting and radiating to the right shoulder and back. The patient also reports feeling nauseous, vomiting, and a low-grade fever. The patient's temperature is found to be slightly elevated, but no signs of chills or jaundice are present. The patient's symptoms started a day after the surgery and have not improved since then.
Medical History:
The patient has a history of gall bladder surgery that was performed a month ago. The patient reports no other significant medical history.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient is found to be alert and oriented. There is no evidence of shock or sepsis. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no guarding or rebound tenderness. There is no evidence of peritonitis or bowel obstruction. The patient's blood pressure and heart rate are within normal limits.
Diagnostic Tests:
A blood test and a urinalysis are performed, which reveal no abnormalities. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, which shows no evidence of an inflammatory process or a bowel obstruction. A CT scan of the abdomen is also performed, which shows no evidence of a bowel obstruction or a surgical site infection.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms, physical examination, and diagnostic tests, the patient is diagnosed with post-operative ileus. This is a common complication after abdominal surgery, which can cause abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever. The patient's symptoms are likely related to the surgery and the bowel being in a state of "ileus," which is a temporary state of obstruction of the small bowel.
Treatment Plan:
The patient is advised to continue to follow up with the surgeon for further evaluation and management of the ileus. The patient is also advised to follow up with the gastroenterologist for further management of the nausea and vomiting. The patient is prescribed anti-emetics and pain medication to manage the symptoms. The patient is also advised to follow up with the surgeon in 2-3 weeks for a follow-up appointment to assess the progress of the ileus.
Conclusion:
The patient presented with a sudden onset of severe right-sided abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever after a gall bladder surgery. The patient's symptoms were consistent with post-operative ileus, which is a common complication after abdominal surgery. The patient was advised to continue to follow up with the surgeon for further evaluation and management

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is an 81-year-old female who presents with a chief complaint of a five-hour-long belly ache accompanied by severe pain, nausea, and vomiting. She reports no recent changes in her diet or any known medical conditions. She has no history of surgeries or illnesses.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient is in mild distress and appears uncomfortable. She reports that the pain is located in the lower abdomen and is constant in nature. She also reports that the pain is accompanied by nausea and vomiting. There is no evidence of peritonitis or other signs of sepsis.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination, a diagnosis of acute appendicitis is made. The patient is referred for further imaging studies, including an abdominal ultrasound and CT scan, to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient is advised to continue to report any changes in her symptoms, including worsening pain, fever, or signs of peritonitis. She is prescribed antibiotics for the treatment of appendicitis and is advised to follow up with the physician in one week for a follow-up examination. If the patient's symptoms worsen or if she develops signs of peritonitis, she is advised to seek emergency medical attention immediately.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 51-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain, difficulty breathing, and a recent tumble. The patient reported that he had taken a fall from a high place and landed hard on his chest and belly, which caused him to experience severe pain. The patient also reported that he has been dealing with high blood pressure for the past five years and had his appendix removed more than two decades ago. The patient's travel history and past medical history were unremarkable.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient was found to be in mild distress and had difficulty breathing. The patient's chest was found to be tender, particularly in the mid-left area. The patient's lungs were auscultated with a normal breath sounds and no wheezing or crackles were heard. The patient's heart rate was found to be normal, but the patient was found to have a slight irregularity in his EKG.
Diagnostic Tests:
The patient underwent a chest X-ray and an EKG, which were both normal. The patient's chest X-ray showed no signs of a fracture or other abnormalities.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms of chest pain, difficulty breathing, and a recent tumble, it is possible that the patient has sustained a rib injury or a lung injury. It is also possible that the patient may have a heart condition. However, the normal results of the chest X-ray and EKG suggest that these are not the most likely causes of the patient's symptoms.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was advised to continue to monitor his symptoms and to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation. The patient was also advised to avoid any activities that may exacerbate his symptoms and to seek medical attention if his symptoms worsen or if he experiences any new symptoms. The patient was also advised to continue taking his blood pressure medication as prescribed by his physician.
Conclusion:
The patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of chest pain, difficulty breathing, and a recent tumble. The patient's examination and diagnostic tests were normal, but the patient's symptoms suggest that he may have sustained a rib injury or a lung injury. The patient was advised to continue to monitor his symptoms and to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the chest and abdomen following a vehicle accident 2 hours ago
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports pain in the chest and abdomen that started 2 hours ago following a vehicle accident. The chest pain is localized to the left side, worsens with deep breathing and coughing, accompanied by mild respiratory difficulty, but no hemoptysis. The abdominal pain is a continuous dull ache, localized to the upper left quadrant, without episodic worsening.
Text.Past Medical History: None
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Thoracic cage without deformity, no evident redness or swelling on the left chest wall, apparent tenderness on palpation from the 3rd to 12th ribs, positive bone crepitus, positive compression test; abdomen flat, mild tenderness on light pressure in the upper left quadrant, no rebound tenderness or muscle rigidity, mild costovertebral angle tenderness over the left kidney, no tenderness over liver or right kidney area, negative shifting dullness, bowel sounds 4-5 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard, negative abdominal puncture.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00024.jpg>.  

 Chest CT: 1. Left-sided pneumohydrothorax, band-like opacities in the lower lobes of both lungs; 2. Small nodules in the right middle and upper lobes; 3. Dilatation of the ascending aorta, aortic wall calcification; 4. Bilateral hilar lymph node calcification; 5. Small amount of effusion in the right thoracic cavity, localized thickening of the right pleura; 6. Fractures of the left 3rd to 12th ribs.
Text.Diagnosis: Blunt trauma to the thoracoabdominal region, abdominal effusion
Text.Treatment: Management includes nil by mouth, fluid replenishment, antibiotics, and nutritional support.

Image.00024.jpg: Irregular contour of the spleen; slightly higher density under the capsule of the left kidney; calcification spot in the right lobe of the liver; thickened gallbladder wall; small amount of abdominal effusion.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 58-year-old male who presents with a chief complaint of severe chest and abdominal pain that started after a car crash. The chest pain is located on the left side and is exacerbated by deep breathing and coughing. The abdominal pain is located in the top left part of the abdomen and is constant and nagging. The patient reports no blood when coughing, but the pain is making it difficult to catch his breath. The patient has no recent travel history, and his past medical history is unremarkable. He is currently not taking any medications or supplements and has not noticed any recent changes in his diet or lifestyle.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient's vital signs are within normal limits. The chest is symmetric and without any signs of inflammation or effusion. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no masses or tenderness. The liver and spleen are not palpable. The patient's cardiovascular and respiratory systems are within normal limits.
Diagnostic Tests:
A chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound were performed, which revealed no abnormalities. The patient's symptoms are consistent with a possible myocardial infarction or a gastrointestinal disorder, but further diagnostic tests such as an EKG, CT scan, or endoscopy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient's symptoms are severe and require immediate attention. The patient should be admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment. The patient should be given oxygen therapy and pain management. Further diagnostic tests such as an EKG, CT scan, or endoscopy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis. The patient should be closely monitored for any changes in his condition and receive appropriate treatment based on the diagnosis. The patient should also be referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of any potential myocardial infarction.

history.patient: I've been feeling like my heart's galloping real fast, and my chest is all tight, as if someone's giving it a good squeeze. diagnosis_self:
Case Report
Patient Presentation:
The patient presented with a chief complaint of dark red vomiting and black, tarry stools for more than three hours. The patient also reported feeling galloping heart, chest pressure, dizziness, and weakness. The patient's symptoms began after vomiting and passing black stools three times.
Examination:
The patient's examination was unremarkable, with no physical findings to suggest a specific diagnosis. The patient's vital signs were within normal limits, and there were no signs of shock or dehydration.
Diagnostic Tests:
To confirm the diagnosis of gastrointestinal bleed, additional tests were performed. The patient's laboratory tests were normal, and the patient's imaging studies were also normal. The patient's history of taking aspirin for high blood pressure and heart issues was also taken into account.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and the results of the diagnostic tests, it was diagnosed that the patient was experiencing a gastrointestinal bleed. The patient's symptoms were consistent with a bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract, and the patient's history of taking aspirin was also considered.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was advised to stop taking aspirin immediately, as it could be contributing to the bleeding. The patient was also advised to avoid taking any other medications that could cause bleeding, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The patient was also advised to avoid consuming foods that could irritate the gastrointestinal tract, such as spicy or fatty foods.
The patient was also advised to take proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) to reduce the production of stomach acid, which could help to prevent further bleeding. The patient was also advised to take blood products if the bleeding was severe.
The patient was also advised to follow up with the doctor in a few days to check the bleeding and to discuss further management options.
Conclusion:
The patient presented with a chief complaint of dark red vomiting and black, tarry stools for more than three hours. The patient's symptoms were consistent with a gastrointestinal bleed, and the patient's history of taking aspirin was also considered. The patient was advised to stop taking aspirin immediately, to avoid taking any other medications that could cause bleeding, and to follow up with the doctor in a few days to check the bleeding and to discuss further management options.

diagnosis_self:
The patient is a 57-year-old male who presents with a persistent upper abdominal pain that has been present for five days. The pain is described as a dull ache that is constant and not located in any particular area. The patient also reports feeling nauseous, with the sensation of vomiting up stomach contents and yellow-green liquid. There is no blood in the vomit. The patient has no fever or respiratory symptoms, and there are no recent travel history or foreign travel. The patient has a history of gallbladder removal and stones in bile ducts, as well as high blood pressure. The patient's examination is normal, with no abnormalities found in the abdomen or chest. The patient's blood pressure is within normal limits.
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination, the most likely diagnosis is a gastrointestinal disorder, such as a peptic ulcer or a gastrointestinal infection. The patient's history of gallbladder removal and stones in bile ducts suggests that the patient may have a history of biliary tract disease, which could also be a contributing factor. The patient's nausea and vomiting are common symptoms of gastrointestinal disorders, and the persistence of these symptoms for five days is concerning. The patient's blood pressure is within normal limits, but this does not rule out the possibility of a gastrointestinal disorder as a cause of the symptoms.
The patient's treatment plan should include further diagnostic testing, such as an upper endoscopy or a CT scan, to determine the cause of the symptoms. The patient should also be prescribed anti-inflammatory medication to reduce inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract. The patient should be advised to avoid spicy foods and alcohol, as these can irritate the gastrointestinal tract. The patient should also be advised to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle, including regular exercise and stress management techniques. The patient should be advised to follow up with the doctor in one week to discuss the results of the diagnostic testing and to discuss the treatment plan.

Text.Chief Complaint: Coughing, expectorating phlegm, and chest pain for 2 months, worsening over the last half month.

He produces a small amount of white viscous sputum, accompanied by bilateral chest wall pain, predominantly on the right side, noticeable during deep inhalation and unrelated to physical activity. No chills, fever, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, hoarseness, chest tightness, palpitations, night sweats, hemoptysis, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, aversion to oils, poor appetite, jaundice, or urinary symptoms like frequency, urgency, or pain. Symptoms worsened half a month ago, and intermittent self-medication with 'penicillin' did not relieve the symptoms.
Text.Past Medical History: Generally in moderate health, underwent surgery for cervical spondylosis over a year ago with metal implantation. Text.Chief Complaint: Upper abdominal pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting for over 5 hours
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports onset of upper abdominal pain 5 hours ago after consuming chicken legs and chicken soup. The pain, which is episodic and intensifies in bursts, is accompanied by nausea and vomiting of stomach contents. The abdominal pain did not ease after vomiting. There were no loose or bloody stools, no fever, no cough or expectoration, and no chest tightness or chest pain. Symptoms did not improve after self-administration of aluminum magnesium suspension.
Text.Past Medical History: History of rheumatoid arthritis and gout for over 7 years, with intermittent hospital treatments and regular oral pain management with fenbid. Similar episode occurred about 2 months ago, which gradually improved after self-medication with aluminum magnesium suspension and other treatments.
Text.Examinations: Upper abdominal CT: <\image00031.jpg>
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes a third-generation cephalosporin with enzyme inhibitor (cefoperazone-sulbactam) for infection, Xuebijing intravenous drip to regulate immune response and suppress inflammation, tracheal intubation with protective ventilation strategy (from 3.25 to 3.30), continuous enteral lavage and catharsis, external application of magnesium sulfate on the abdomen, and bilateral lower limb movement therapy on a rehabilitation bicycle to promote intestinal motility. Antibiotics adjusted to meropenem in combination with vancomycin.

Image.00031.jpg: Changes around the head of the pancreas, suggesting the possibility of pancreatitis.

检查报告: Upper abdominal CT: <\image00031.jpg>
治疗: Treatment includes a third-generation cephalosporin with enzyme inhibitor (cefoperazone-sulbactam) for infection, Xuebijing intravenous drip to regulate immune response and suppress inflammation, tracheal intubation with protective ventilation strategy (from 3.25 to 3.30), continuous enteral lavage and catharsis, external application of magnesium sulfate on the abdomen, and bilateral lower limb movement therapy on a rehabilitation bicycle to promote intestinal motility. Antibiotics adjusted to meropenem in combination with vancomycin.

图片.00031.jpg: Changes around the head of the pancreas, suggesting the possibility of pancreatitis.

Text.Chief Complaint: Presenting to our hospital due to 'fever and headache for 7 days'.
Text.Present Illness: The patient started experiencing fever 7 days ago, with temperatures reaching up to 37.5°C, and headaches affecting the entire head, occurring intermittently and lasting about 30 minutes each. The headaches, sometimes unbearable, did not respond well to oral pain medication occasionally and did not show a clear correlation with body position. Headaches occurred even when her temperature was normal.
Text.Past Medical History: 45 days ago, the patient had a fever peaking at 39°C with chills, tested positive for the novel coronavirus, followed by a decrease in temperature. 15 days ago, she again developed a fever reaching 38°C, with no cough or expectoration, testing positive for coronavirus antigen. Intermittently took ibuprofen. Denies any history of diabetes, kidney diseases, surgeries, trauma, blood transfusions, and has been vaccinated against COVID-19.
Text.Examinations:
Cranial CT: <\image00032.jpg>.  

 First lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 300 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 420×10^6/L, red blood cells 140×10^6/L, white blood cells 280×10^6/L, 80% polymorphonuclear cells, 20% mononuclear cells.  

 CSF biochemistry: Protein 0.64 g/L, glucose 2.0 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 8.4 mmol/L), lactate 2.4 mmol/L. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus.  

 Second lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 150 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 190×10^6/L, red blood cells 90×10^6/L, white blood cells 100×10^6/L, 64% polymorphonuclear cells, 36% mononuclear cells. Biochemistry: Protein 0.34 g/L, glucose 2.4 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 5.2 mmol/L), lactate 1.8 mmol/L. Adenosine deaminase in CSF 2.4 U/L, in blood 24 U/L. No bacteria seen on Gram stain, no acid-fast bacilli on acid-fast stain. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus. CSF culture showed no bacterial growth. Tuberculosis infection T-cell test negative.  

 CSF cytology: Abnormal, predominantly lymphocytic.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 5 months, rifampin 0.6g twice daily for 5 months, and ceftriaxone 2g twice daily intravenously for infection control and symptomatic treatment.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient presented with a chief complaint of a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. The headache was described as being "vice-like" and causing significant discomfort. The patient also reported feeling sick to their stomach and having lost their lunch multiple times. The patient's past medical history includes high blood pressure, which is being managed with amlodipine. The patient has no history of travel outside the United States and no other significant medical conditions.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient was found to be normotensive and had a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. The patient was also found to have a pulse rate of 72 beats per minute and a blood oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's examination was otherwise unremarkable.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings, a diagnosis of a headache secondary to high blood pressure was made. The patient's symptoms were consistent with a headache due to hypertension, which is a common complication of hypertension. The patient's nausea and vomiting were also consistent with the symptoms of a headache secondary to hypertension.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was prescribed a beta-blocker to help lower their blood pressure and alleviate their headache. The patient was also advised to increase their blood pressure medication as needed. The patient was also instructed to avoid any activities that may worsen their symptoms, such as eating heavy or spicy foods, and to seek medical attention if their symptoms worsen or do not improve.
Conclusion:
The patient presented with a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting, which were consistent with a headache secondary to hypertension. The patient was prescribed a beta-blocker to help lower their blood pressure and alleviate their symptoms. The patient was also advised to increase their blood pressure medication as needed and to avoid any activities that may worsen their symptoms. Further evaluation and management of the patient's hypertension is recommended.
